content: The Act titled "Stop Child Pornographers and Predators Act" prohibits obscenity depicting young children. PROHIBITION ON USE OF MATERIALS TO FACILITATE OFFENSES AGAINST MINORS. Chapter 71 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to prohibit the use of obscene material or child pornography to facilitate offenses against minors. SEC. 4. EXTRATERRITORIAL PRODUCTION OF CHILD PORNOGRAPHY FOR DISTRIBUTION IN THE UNITED STATES. Section 2251 is amended to include provisions for punishing individuals who engage minors in sexually explicit conduct outside the United States for the purpose of producing visual depictions. The amended Section 2251 punishes individuals who transport or make available visual depictions of minors engaged in sexually explicit conduct in the United States. SEC. 5. IMPRISONMENT FOR REPEAT SEX OFFENDERS AGAINST CHILDREN. Section 3559 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to allow up to life imprisonment for repeated Federal sex offenses against children. This applies to individuals with a prior sex conviction involving a minor victim. The definition of a Federal sex offense includes various offenses related to child exploitation and abuse. The amendment to Section 3559 of title 18, United States Code allows for life imprisonment for repeated Federal sex offenses against children, including offenses related to child exploitation and abuse under various sections of the law. The term 'prior sex conviction' in Federal law refers to a previous conviction for a sex offense that occurred in specific locations or involved interstate commerce, foreign commerce, or the use of the mails. The term 'prior sex conviction' refers to a conviction for a Federal or State sex offense imposed before the subsequent offense, 'minor' is defined as an individual under 17 years old, and 'State' has the meaning as defined in subsection (c)(2).
